(a) We consider the arrangements by taking 2 particular children counted as one and hence the remaining 4 can be arranged in 4P4 or 4!. We can use either FCP or nPr formula.
Therefore, there are 24 × 2 = 48 total ways of arrangement.
(b) Among the 5! = 120 permutations of 5 children, there are 48 in which two children are together. In the remaining 120 – 48 = 72 permutations, two particular children are never together.
